items.synopsis: New data reveals how households that have been under interest rate pressure for more than 18 months are managing to make ends meet.

title.children: When something has to give, which bill payments do you miss? New NZ data has some clues

image.altText: King Charles and a smiling Anthony Albanese look at the camera as they shake hands

items.synopsis: The prime minister is putting aside his republican views to pledge allegiance to King Charles III to honour 'the system of government we have', but believes the day will come when Australia stands on its own two feet.

title.children: Albanese says 'it's not up to me' to refuse pledge of allegiance to King Charles

image.altText: An older man is carried on a stretcher past a train by men wearing military helmets and vests.

items.synopsis: Moscow steps up strikes on Ukraine as Kyiv prepares for a counteroffensive in which it is expected to try to retake occupied territory in the Kherson region.

title.children: Russia says United States ordered Ukrainian 'drone strike' on Kremlin, as 23 die in Kherson

image.altText: A picture of Westmead Hospital in the western Sydney suburb of Parramatta

items.synopsis: It is unclear when cyber criminals managed to breach the Crown Princess Mary Cancer Centre, which is part of Westmead Hospital, but NSW Health officials said they were alerted to the threat late on Thursday afternoon.

title.children: Major cancer treatment centre in cyber attack, hackers demand $100,000 ransom for stolen data

image.altText: Two women in a meeting room being questioned by a man

items.synopsis: Senior public servants were prepared to accept the reality of racism in Victoria's criminal justice and child protection systems during this week's hearings at the Yoorrook Justice Commission. But reporter Kate Ashton asks whether that's all Victoria's truth-telling inquiry is looking for.

title.children: 'You just don't listen': In Victoria's Yoorrook inquiry, a colonial institution is being called to account

image.altText: A woman in a hijab with her arms crossed in front of a house

items.synopsis: More than a dozen African-Australian families who lodged a human rights commission complaint three years ago alleging racism and bullying by staff at a Melbourne school say the school involved is yet to properly acknowledge their experiences.

title.children: African-Australian families detail allegations of bullying and racism at Melbourne primary school

image.altText: An elderly man wearing a cap and a facemask on his chin

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: US denies Russian 'lies' over Kremlin explosions, and Father Bob's state funeral. Catch up with The Loop

schema.headline: The Loop live: US denies Russian 'lies' over Kremlin drone attack, Father Bob's state funeral, and royal fans set up for King Charles's coronation

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Napoli win their first Serie A title in 33 years
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Napoli have won their third Serie A title — and their first in 33 years — after a 1-1 draw at Udinese secured an unassailable lead in the standings. Napoli's triumph ended the city's long wait for the Scudetto since Argentine great Diego Maradona led them to two championships in 1986-87 and 1989-90. A second-half goal by Victor Osimhen secured Napoli the title with five games remaining in the season. As the final whistle blew, Napoli supporters rushed onto the pitch to celebrate the momentous occasion alongside the players. Napoli have 80 points, securing their position at the top of the table. Second-placed Lazio, who also have five games left to play, are 16 points behind.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ukraine says it shot down its own drone flying out of control over Kyiv
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Ukraine's air force says it has destroyed one of its own drones after it started flying out of control over Kyiv. "On 4th May at about 8 p.m. during a planned flight in Kyiv region, control was lost over a Baykartar TV2 drone," the air force said in a statement on Telegram. "As the uncontrolled flight of the drone in skies over the capital could have led to undesirable consequences, the decision was taken to use mobile fire groups. The target - destroyed!" The statement says the drone probably suffered a technical failure. The drone appears to be the one captured in the video below, which was filmed flying over Kyiv before being shot down.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ed Sheeran wins copyright case brought by Marvin Gay's heirs
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In case you missed this news from overnight — singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran has won a copyright case which was brought against him by the heirs of music legend Marvin Gay. A jury in a Manhattan federal court has decided Sheeran's 2014 hit Thinking Out Loud did not unlawfully copy Marvin Gaye's 1973 song Let's Get It On. Sheeran says he is "not a piggy bank to shake", and is "devastated" to be accused of stealing someone else's song. "I want to thank the jury for making the decision that will help protect the creative process for songwriters here in the United States and all around the world," he says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US denies it was responsible for alleged drone attack on the Kremlin
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The White House has dismissed what it calls Russian "lies" alleging the United States was responsible for a purported drone attack against the Kremlin in Moscow. Russia claims the US was behind what it says was a drone attack on the Kremlin which aimed to kill President Vladimir Putin. White House national security spokesperson John Kirby says there is still no conclusive evidence as to the authenticity of a video showing the alleged drone attack. Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, without providing evidence, said Ukraine had acted on US orders when it launched what Russia said was a drone attack on the Kremlin building in the early hours of Wednesday morning. "We know very well that decisions about such actions, about such terrorist attacks, are made not in Kyiv but in Washington," Mr Peskov said. Kirby said the US did not encourage or enable Ukraine to strike outside its borders. "I can assure you that there was no involvement by the United States in this. Whatever it was did not involve us," Mr Kirby told cable news network MSNBC. "We still don't really know what happened." Ukraine also denied involvement in the incident, which followed a string of explosions over the past week targeting freight trains and oil depots in western Russia and Russian-controlled Crimea.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australia is searching for: Queen Charlotte
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Netflix series Bridgerton is back, this time with a prequel about the rise of Queen Charlotte. But, as my colleague Jessica Riga points out, it's a "fiction inspired by fact", where all liberties taken are "quite intentional". Before you dive into the show, check out Jessica's piece below about what we know about the real Queen Charlotte.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Father Bob to be farewelled at public state funeral today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Father Bob Maguire, the Catholic priest known for his charitable work and irreverent sense of humour, will be farewelled with a state funeral in Melbourne today. The funeral, to be held from 11am at St Patrick's Cathedral in East Melbourne, will be open to the public but also live-streamed online. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has said the service will "celebrate the life and work of a great Victorian. For our state, and the whole nation". In lieu of flowers and at the request of Father' Bob's family, the Father Bob Foundation is calling for donations to continue its work. The much-loved priest died late last month, aged 88.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing: Royal fans are setting up camp for King Charles's coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Locals and tourists alike are securing their spots for King Charles III's coronation, which takes place in London tomorrow. You can read up on the ABC's broadcast plans here. Until then, here are some fresh pictures of some of the most elaborate setups and keenest royal watchers:

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: The Loop live: US denies Russian 'lies' over Kremlin drone attack, Father Bob's state funeral, and royal fans set up for King Charles's coronation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Napoli have won their third Serie A title — and their first in 33 years — after a 1-1 draw at Udinese secured an unassailable lead in the standings. Napoli's triumph ended the city's long wait for the Scudetto since Argentine great Diego Maradona led them to two championships in 1986-87 and 1989-90. A second-half goal by Victor Osimhen secured Napoli the title with five games remaining in the season. As the final whistle blew, Napoli supporters rushed onto the pitch to celebrate the momentous occasion alongside the players. Napoli have 80 points, securing their position at the top of the table. Second-placed Lazio, who also have five games left to play, are 16 points behind.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The White House has dismissed what it calls Russian "lies" alleging the United States was responsible for a purported drone attack against the Kremlin in Moscow. Russia claims the US was behind what it says was a drone attack on the Kremlin which aimed to kill President Vladimir Putin. White House national security spokesperson John Kirby says there is still no conclusive evidence as to the authenticity of a video showing the alleged drone attack. Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, without providing evidence, said Ukraine had acted on US orders when it launched what Russia said was a drone attack on the Kremlin building in the early hours of Wednesday morning. "We know very well that decisions about such actions, about such terrorist attacks, are made not in Kyiv but in Washington," Mr Peskov said. Kirby said the US did not encourage or enable Ukraine to strike outside its borders. "I can assure you that there was no involvement by the United States in this. Whatever it was did not involve us," Mr Kirby told cable news network MSNBC. "We still don't really know what happened." Ukraine also denied involvement in the incident, which followed a string of explosions over the past week targeting freight trains and oil depots in western Russia and Russian-controlled Crimea.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Father Bob Maguire, the Catholic priest known for his charitable work and irreverent sense of humour, will be farewelled with a state funeral in Melbourne today. The funeral, to be held from 11am at St Patrick's Cathedral in East Melbourne, will be open to the public but also live-streamed online. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has said the service will "celebrate the life and work of a great Victorian. For our state, and the whole nation". In lieu of flowers and at the request of Father' Bob's family, the Father Bob Foundation is calling for donations to continue its work. The much-loved priest died late last month, aged 88.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Father Bob to be farewelled at public state funeral today

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has said the service will "celebrate the life and work of a great Victorian. For our state, and the whole nation".

The much-loved priest died late last month, aged 88.

image.altText: A close-up of a man with grey hair looking to the side, not smiling.

items.synopsis: Senior Victorian Liberals have already begun discussing if MP Moira Deeming should be expelled from the party room over her threats to sue Opposition Leader John Pesutto.

title.children: Exiled MP Moira Deeming tells Opposition Leader John Pesutto she is taking legal action over her suspension

image.altText: An illustration of a woman's profile with a squiggly line where her brain is. She's surrounded by water

items.synopsis: Menopause marks the end of a woman's reproductive stage, but it can also spell the beginning of changes in the way we think and feel. So how does oestrogen affect the brain?

title.children: Irritable? Teary? Anxious? How menopause can affect how we think and feel

image.altText: A tight head shot of an Aboriginal woman with dyed blonde hair.

items.synopsis: Margaret Hawke will learn of her punishment today for the murder of her three children, just hours after seeking support, in a tragedy prompting calls for more mining revenue to be channelled back into the Port Hedland community.

title.children: As a mother awaits sentencing for killing her children, her town wants help to stop future tragedies

image.altText: A husband and wife overlook their garden while holding a wheelbarrow.

items.synopsis: Many Australian retirees are returning to the workforce these days. For some, it's out of necessity; for others, it's for more philosophical reasons.

title.children: Thousands of retired Australians are rejoining the workforce. Here's why

image.altText: People wearing warm clothes outside Sydney Opera House

items.synopsis: Polar winds will send temperatures diving this weekend, making for the coldest early May weather for three years across the southern and eastern states.

title.children: Weekend cold snap to see temperatures drop, snow, hail and thunder

image.altText: King Chalres and Albanese smile at each other as they shake hands in a lavish room of Buckingham Palace

items.synopsis: If, as speculated, the budget predicts a 2022-23 surplus, that further complicates the opposition's reaction. The Coalition is stymied, whether it attacks from the right or (less likely) the left, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Awkward questions for Albanese overseas as an intense tug of war builds at home

image.altText: Katy Gallagher wearing a black jacket and purple top, looking to the right

items.synopsis: A series of parliamentary inquiries found the mutual obligations element of the program to be punitive and "akin to coercive control".

title.children: Federal government to abolish 'polarising' ParentsNext scheme

image.altText: Victorian power - Snowy Hydro

items.synopsis: A bitter rift between the former boss of state-owned power provider Snowy Hydro and federal Energy Minister Chris Bowen has widened following claims Labor's green energy plans are not achievable.

title.children: Fuse blown as former Snowy Hydro boss takes aim at 'bulls**t' renewable energy goals

image.altText: a man with blood coming from his mouth after being hit

items.synopsis: Referee Khodr Yaghi suffered a broken jaw after being assaulted while officiating a match in Sydney's south last week.

title.children: Sydney soccer referees to wear body cameras after alleged assault at match

image.altText: Prime Minister Kalsakau and Penny Wong sign a security agreement

items.synopsis: Anxieties are growing in Canberra that a landmark security agreement between Australia and Vanuatu could stall in the Pacific nation's parliament.

title.children: Fears domestic Vanuatu politics could foil important security pact with Australia

image.altText: Ms Lamb sits in a wheelchair and looks over her fence towards the camera.

items.synopsis: As talks about how to make the NDIS more sustainable ramp up again, people with disability say a good place to start would be with the costly and "exhausting" red tape.

title.children: Rayna needed a new wheelchair cushion but the paperwork alone cost her over $1,000

image.altText: Penny Wong smiling, wearing a flower crown and lei over formal clothing

items.synopsis: A wide-ranging Pacific assistance package covering environmental, military, and economic support for Australia's closest neighbours will be unveiled in Tuesday's budget.

title.children: Australia to increase Pacific engagement with multi-million-dollar 'whole of government' budget package

image.altText: Proud Boys chairman Enrique Tarrio at a far-right rally.

items.synopsis: A jury has convicted four members of the far-right Proud Boys militia group, finding they plotted to attack the US Capitol in a failed bid to block Congress from certifying President Joe Biden's 2021 election victory.

title.children: Jury convicts Proud Boys members of seditious conspiracy in US Capitol attack

image.altText: Singer Ed Sheeran smiles while speaking to the media outside a Manhattan court.

items.synopsis: British pop superstar Ed Sheeran's 2014 hit Thinking Out Loud did not unlawfully copy Marvin Gaye's classic 1973 song Let's Get It On, a Manhattan jury decides.

title.children: US jury sides with Ed Sheeran in Let's Get It On copyright trial

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The nurses union warns the aged care sector has form when it comes to avoiding paying wage rises, and says the government must oblige providers to pass on a historic 15 per cent pay increase to all workers, not just those on award rates.

title.children: Nurses union fears nursing homes won't pass on 'historic' $11.3 billion budget commitment to boost aged care wages

image.altText: A man walking in a suit outside court

items.synopsis: Adam Cranston is one of five people found guilty of two charges over various roles in the Plutus Payroll scam, which ran for about three years to 2017.

title.children: Judge 'flabbergasted' legal aid pulled for one of architects of $105m tax fraud

image.altText: University staff march down a street, waving union flags and holding signs that say "I'm on strike!"

items.synopsis: University tutors who say they cannot plan for their futures are among the thousands of university staff to walk off the job as part of a national week of action against insecure work and wage theft.

title.children: 'Unprecedented' university strike in Melbourne to continue after years of 'anger and discontent'

image.altText: The logos of the four big banks in Australia

items.synopsis: Here is a breakdown of which major banks have responded to the RBA's decision, and which ones we're still waiting on.

title.children: Which banks are changing their interest rates as the RBA makes its 11th increase in 12 months

image.altText: Coach Anju Jain passes on some advice to a young female player on the cricket field.

items.synopsis: The glitter has well and truly settled on the inaugural WPL, and now India's female cricket coaches are stepping into the spotlight.

title.children: 'This was life-changing': India's female cricket coaches reaping benefits of WPL a month on

image.altText: Two men smile in an image composite.

items.synopsis: One of two police officers attacked and stabbed in SA's Mid North has been discharged from hospital while the other is showing "positive progress" following surgery for critical injuries last night, the state's police commissioner says.

title.children: Stabbed SA policeman discharged from hospital, other showing 'positive progress' following surgery

image.altText: A police cordon and police car out the front of a suburban Darwin home

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police say they are treating the death of Md Ishaqur Rahman Sifat, 23, as a homicide. A man remains in custody but has not been charged.

title.children: International student dies in Darwin hospital after violent home invasion

image.altText: A helicopter landed on an oval.

items.synopsis: The Australian Defence Force says it is making inquiries after a helicopter painted in army colours that is no longer part of its fleet made an emergency landing in Melbourne this afternoon.

title.children: Defence force says camo helicopter that made emergency landing on suburban oval not in army fleet

image.altText: A woman with a black spot on her nose

items.synopsis: When 42-year-old Nicolette Jane noticed a red, itchy lump on her nose, she went to straight to her GP, as a new study highlights the huge job doctors are undertaking to detect skin cancer.

title.children: GPs playing increasingly pivotal role in detecting skin cancer in Australians

image.altText: Five people sitting in the jury dock, an old woman in a tie dye tshirt at the centre clapping

items.synopsis: The comedy series has a crazy premise - an entirely fake court case where everyone involved is an actor except one sweet schmuck - but the result is funny and unexpectedly moving.

title.children: Why the internet is going gaga for 'fake doco' Jury Duty and lovable protagonist Ronald Gladden

image.altText: A still from the show compared to a portrait of Queen Charlotte where both women are in similar outfits with blue hats.

items.synopsis: Bridgerton is back in the cultural zeitgeist thanks to its new prequel charting the rise to prominence and power of Queen Charlotte. But just how much of the show is true to life?

title.children: The new Bridgerton prequel is 'fiction inspired by fact'. So who was the real Queen Charlotte?

image.altText: Artist impression of interior view of sporting event underway at proposed Te Kaha stadium.

items.synopsis: While the design for Hobart's Macquarie Point stadium is a way off, AFL boss Gillon McLachlan has made it clear it will have a roof and, it may well be see-through. But what will it mean for cricket and concerts?

title.children: How will cricket work at a new Hobart stadium if there's a roof?

image.altText: Multiple people in high vis gear standing around a door archway

items.synopsis: Authorities believe the eight people who died in the blaze were homeless who were occupying abandoned buildings where a new neighbourhood is planned to be built.

title.children: Eight people die in building containers fire in Czechia

image.altText: A woman stands in flood water next to debris.

items.synopsis: Flooding and landslides kill at least 129 people in Rwanda and six in Uganda, as rescuers search for survivors.

title.children: Flooding, landslides kill at least 135 in Rwanda and Uganda
